description:
Wikispecies 
From Middle English hind, hinde, hynde, from Old English hind, Proto-West Germanic *hindu, from Proto-Germanic *hindÅ, *hindiz, from a formation on Proto-Indo-European *á¸±em- (â€œhornlessâ€). Cognate with Dutch hinde, German Hinde, Danish hind.

entries.meaning: A female deer, especially a red deer at least two years old.
A spotted food fish of the genus Epinephelus.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A servant, especially an agricultural labourer.
examples: The peaceful tenour of Nina's life was interrupted one morning by the mysterious looks and whisperings of her maids and hinds.
